plain_language_summary:
Reviewing Immigration Policies to Reduce Illegal Immigration Funding

Overview: Executive Order 14113 directs federal agencies to review their immigration-related policies, guidance, and practices. The goal is to identify and eliminate any federal funding that directly or indirectly supports illegal immigration.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions should assess whether any of their federal funding could be at risk due to direct or indirect support of illegal immigration.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal Grants: Review federal grants to ensure compliance with immigration-related eligibility requirements.

Financial Aid: Confirm student aid is not inadvertently supporting students engaged in illegal immigration.

Research Funding: Evaluate research funding sources and projects for any immigration-related risks.

Affected Departments:

Government Affairs, Financial Aid Office, Research Administration, Legal Counsel

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes, institutions should proactively review policies and funding for potential immigration compliance gaps.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review the institution's policies related to verifying immigration status.
  • Identify federal funding streams with immigration-related eligibility criteria.
  • Meet with affected departments to coordinate an immigration compliance review.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Audit federal grants, financial aid, and research funding for immigration risks.
  • Develop an action plan to remediate any identified compliance gaps.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Monitor evolving federal immigration policies for impact on the institution.
  • Provide immigration compliance training to relevant personnel.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Staff time to conduct immigration compliance review and remediation.

Budget: Potential need for outside immigration counsel. Possible reduction in federal aid/funding.

Technology: Systems to track/verify immigration status may need enhancement.

External Expertise: Immigration legal counsel to assist with compliance review.

comprehensive_analysis:
Assessing Federal Funding Streams for Immigration Compliance Risks

Overview: Executive Order 14113, titled 'Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Open Borders', initiates a broad federal review of immigration-related policies, guidance, procedures and practices. The stated intention is to identify and eliminate any sources of federal funding that are directly or indirectly supporting illegal immigration. For higher education institutions, this means assessing whether any federal aid, grants, or research dollars could be at risk due to insufficient immigration compliance controls.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions need to proactively audit their federal funding streams and related compliance practices to surface and address any potential issues regarding improper support of illegal immigration. Both direct funding and pass-through funding are in scope.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

U.S. immigration enforcement has been contentious across recent administrations. This EO escalates matters by tying immigration concerns to federal funding, which is a critical revenue stream for many colleges and universities.

Legal Framework:

Various statutes restrict federal public benefits to U.S. citizens or certain legal immigrants (e.g. 8 USC §§1611, 1621). But application to higher education has had limited enforcement to date.

Higher Education Context:

Higher education is under mounting scrutiny and financial pressure on multiple fronts. Losing access to federal funding over immigration issues would be devastating for many institutions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal Student Aid: Review eligibility criteria, verification procedures, and disbursement practices for federal financial aid to ensure only legal recipients.

Research Grants: Assess research personnel, partnerships, and funding sources for immigration-related risks and proper oversight.

Other Grants/Contracts: Systematically audit all other federal funding agreements to identify any with immigration status requirements for participation.

Enrollment Management: Admissions, registration and student support processes should be evaluated for sufficient immigration compliance and documentation.

Sponsored Programs: Build immigration compliance reviews into processes for pursuing federal funding opportunities and managing awarded projects.

Affected Departments:

Financial Aid Office, Research Administration, Sponsored Programs Office, Enrollment Management, Government Affairs, Legal Counsel, Administration & Finance

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Leverage existing Form I-9 and E-Verify employment eligibility verification processes as well as SEVIS tracking for international students. Ensure consistent processes and documentation of legal immigration status across all areas related to federal funding eligibility.

Technical Analysis:

Federal funding agreements likely to require certifications of institutional immigration compliance, so underlying procedures and systems must be sufficiently sophisticated and deterministic to support such certifications.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

An immigration compliance review regarding federal funds will necessarily touch many areas and require extensive cross-departmental cooperation to be effective. Upfront coordination is critical.

Risk Analysis:

Significant compliance risk from lack of consistent, verifiable immigration procedures for federal fund recipients. But overcorrecting also poses risks (e.g. national origin discrimination). Expert guidance is essential.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions with tighter oversight of immigration matters may have an advantage in competing for federal funding. Those reliant on federal aid for undocumented/DACA students are at serious risk.

Long-term Vision:

Immigration will remain a key issue for higher ed federal policy. Developing maturity and consistency in compliance approaches will be critical for securing an institution's funding future.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher education associations will likely coordinate efforts to help shape reasonable implementation parameters. Individual institutions can engage as appropriate for their circumstances.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes, this EO demands a thorough institutional review of federal funding exposure and proactive remediation of any deficiencies - both to safeguard current funding and preserve future opportunities.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief senior leadership on the EO and develop an action plan for an immigration compliance review.
  • Identify all federal funding streams and the associated immigration-related requirements.
  • Pinpoint high-risk areas such as financial aid, sponsored research, and admissions for priority attention.
  • Engage experienced immigration counsel to support the compliance assessment and remediation planning.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Complete cross-functional immigration compliance audit of federal funding lifecycles - from application through closeout.
  • Identify and implement corrective actions for any compliance gaps, with particular urgency for areas with current funding.
  • Update policies, procedures, training, and documentation to ensure ongoing immigration compliance.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Make immigration compliance a core competency with clear roles and governance processes.
  • Monitor developments in federal immigration enforcement that could impact eligibility for future funding.
  • Consider strategic/legal input to federal implementation to mitigate overreach.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Significant staff/faculty time needed for compliance review and remediation across multiple departments. Central compliance lead role likely required.

Budget: Third-party immigration counsel will add expense. Potential for reduced federal aid revenue and increased operational costs for enhanced compliance.

Technology: May need system enhancements for consolidated immigration status tracking across the organization and reporting to federal funders.

External Expertise: External immigration compliance experts will be needed to effectively assess risks and design compliant procedures and controls.
